start.title: Chappie
start.creator_credit: Neill Blomkamp, Diana Cilliers, Julian Clarke, Mark Goldblatt, Simon Kinberg, Columbia Pictures, Genre Films, LStar Capital, MRC, Jules Cook and Terri Tatchell
start.brief_description: Every child comes into the world full of promise, and none more so than Chappie: he is gifted, special, a prodigy. Like any child, Chappie will come under the influence of his surroundings—some good, some bad—and he will rely on his heart and soul to find his way in the world and become his own man. But there’s one thing that makes Chappie different from any one else: he is a robot.

end.title: Prisoners
end.creator_credit: Denis Villeneuve, Renée April, Gary D. Roach, Joel Cox, Adam Kolbrenner, Andrew A. Kosove, Broderick Johnson, Kira Davis, 8:38 Productions, Alcon Entertainment, Madhouse Entertainment, Summit Entertainment, Warner Bros. Pictures, Patrice Vermette and Aaron Guzikowski
end.brief_description: Keller Dover is facing every parent’s worst nightmare. His six-year-old daughter, Anna, is missing, together with her young friend, Joy, and as minutes turn to hours, panic sets in. The only lead is a dilapidated RV that had earlier been parked on their street.

end.title: Elysium
end.creator_credit: Neill Blomkamp, April Ferry, Giorgio Armani, Julian Clarke, Lee Smith, Bill Block, Simon Kinberg, Alphacore, Genre Films, MRC, QED International, TriStar Pictures and Philip Ivey
end.brief_description: In the year 2159, two classes of people exist: the very wealthy who live on a pristine man-made space station called Elysium, and the rest, who live on an overpopulated, ruined Earth. Secretary Rhodes, a hard line government ofﬁcial, will stop at nothing to enforce anti-immigration laws and preserve the luxurious lifestyle of the citizens of Elysium. That doesn’t stop the people of Earth from trying to get in, by any means they can. When unlucky Max is backed into a corner, he agrees to take on a daunting mission that, if successful, will not only save his life, but could bring equality to these polarized worlds.

links.description: A hallmark of director Neill Blomkamp’s films is his focus on the heart beating in dystopias and the moral bankruptcy of so-called utopian visions. In Chappie, Hugh Jackman appears alongside a droid programmed with feelings.

results.name: Dystopian futures & horrific pasts
results.description: For an industry that leans strongly toward happy endings, it's interesting to note that a lot of futures that are speculated in film are dystopic.  However we don't need to look too far to find horrors in the past and present.

key_work.title: Tank girl
key_work.creator_credit: Rachel Talalay, John Watson, Pen Densham, Richard Lewis, Trilogy Entertainment Group and United Artists Corporation
key_work.brief_description: The year is 2033 and water is a precious commodity. In the desolate wind swept plains, animals are banned, bathing is unheard of, and the Water & Power Company, headed by the villainous Kesslee (Malcolm McDowell), have ultimate control over the precious H20. One rebel girl stands in their way, Rebecca (Lori Petty), a chick with attitude and an outrageous hairstyle. She is captured by Water & Power when they kill her boyfriend, kidnap her young friend, and try to blackmail her into joining their team. As a prisoner Rebecca discovers a new passion- tanks, and makes a friend with mechanic and pilot, Jet Girl (Naomi Watts), who helps her escape. Once free the girls join forces with The Rippers, an army of half men and half kangaroos, genetically modified to be the ultimate fighting machines. Together they take Water & Power head on, lead by Jet Girl in the sky, and tank girl on the ground with her beloved tank in a flurry of live action and comic strip visuals. Cast also includes Ice-T, Don Harvey and Jeff Kober.

end.title: Freddy's Dead: The Final Nightmare
end.creator_credit: Aron Warner and Robert Shaye
end.brief_description: Just when you thought it was safe to sleep, Freddy Krueger returns in this sixth installment of the Nightmare on Elm Street films, as psychologist Maggie Burroughs, tormented by recurring nightmares, meets a patient with the same horrific dreams. Their quest for answers leads to a certain house on Elm Street — where the nightmares become reality.

end.brief_description: Taking an ill-advised detour en route to California, the Carter family soon run into trouble when their RV breaks down in the middle of the desert. Stranded, they find themselves at the mercy of monstrous cannibals lurking in the surrounding hills.

links.description: Freddy’s Dead: The Final Nightmare was of course based on the original film by director Wes Craven., A Nightmare on Elm Street (1984). Prior to that, his 1977 horror classic The Hills Have Eyes did away with the supernatural to craft a horrific vision of life outside city limits.

links.description: The Gorillaz’ Clint Eastwood music video begins with a quote from George A. Romero’s Dawn of the Dead: “Every dead body that is not exterminated, gets up and kills. The people it kills, get up and kill”. This quote serves as a nod to the apocalyptic horror film and a lead in to Jamie Hewlett animated punk aesthetic.

results.name: Outliers of the Hollywood musical
results.description: It might feel like the musical genre has been resting since the golden age of cinema, but you only need to look at how many music videos have been produced - especially since the launch of MTV in 1981 - to realise that it isn't. These days, if we count narrative-based music videos, the overwhelming majority that are made are short, snappy and live outside of the Hollywood studio system.

key_work.title: Dancer in the dark
key_work.creator_credit: Lars Von Trier, Vibeke Windelov, Arte France, France 3 Cinema, Trust Film Svenska and Zentropa Entertainment
key_work.brief_description: ‘Dancer in the dark’ is simultaneously an ode to the Hollywood musical, an experiment in digital filmmaking, and a wholly unique, landmark film in contemporary cinema. Similar to ‘Breaking the waves’ and ‘The Idiots’, it centres on a martyr-like female character who is put through excruciating sacrifice and suffering. The setting is rural, 1950s America. Selma (played by Icelandic pop star, Bjork), a Czech immigrant, works day and night to save money for an eye operation that will prevent her son from inheriting an eyesight condition that currently plagues her. What Selma lacks in vision, she makes up for in imagination. ‘Dancer in the dark’ is punctuated with extended fantasy musical sequences in which the drabness of the everyday is transformed into something fantastic, joyous, rhythmic and utopian. Though she enjoys the support of friends, including her best friend Kathy (Catherine Deneuve) and neighbour Bill (David Morse), and is active in the local theatre group, things go from bad to worse for Selma. Loss of financial security and crude betrayal leads to murder, death and an overall Herculean sense of tragedy. Von Trier does many fascinating things in this film. Though he partakes in the Dogme tradition - which seeks to strip away the complete artifice of cinema and usher in the ‘real’ through only ‘natural’ means - Von Trier also reworks and questions it. He does so by juxtaposing documentary-style, almost ‘home-video’ footage, with extremely dazzling, technologically sophisticated, emotionally delirious musical numbers. By throwing together opposite cinematic styles, pushing the characters, the story and the audience to absolute limits of emotional intensity and melodrama, Von Trier not only brings out the essence of the musical as a boundless, overwhelming force, but also asks questions about cinema itself and its powers of storytelling in a post-modern, digital age.

end.title: The Red balloon = Le Ballon rouge
end.creator_credit: Albert Lamorisse and Films Montsouris
end.brief_description: A small boy finds a balloon which follows him everywhere and fills his need for friendship. When the balloon ultimately lifts the child to the sky, it’s a liberating expression of the freedom of childhood. Based on the story by Albert Lamorisse. No dialogue. (Awards: Academy Award, Best Original Screenplay; Cannes, Best Short Film)

These days, if we count narrative-based music videos, the overwhelming majority that are made are short, snappy and live outside of the Hollywood studio system.

links.description: Daft Punk’s Guy-Manuel de Homem-Christo collaborated with Charlotte Gainsbourg on her track Rest, as Co-Writer and Producer. Well before that, Daft Punk’s debut music video Da Funk, directed by Spike Jonze helped elevate the music video artform in the mid-90s.

results.name: Networks and connections
results.description: Just like the expansive underground fungal network revealed in Fungi: The Web of Life, artistic collaboration creates an unseen network between artworks.

key_work.title: Fungi: The Web of Life
key_work.creator_credit: Gisela Kaufmann, Joseph Nizeti, Paul Phelan, David Gross, Jennifer Peedom, Jo-anne McGowan, Sarah Noonan, Definition Films, Stranger Than Fiction Films and Catherine Marciniak
key_work.brief_description: Much of life on Earth is connected by a vast, hidden network that we are only just beginning to understand. Out of sight, between the world of plants and animals, another world exists—the kingdom of fungi.

end.title: River
end.creator_credit: Jennifer Peedom, Joseph Nizeti, Simon Njoo, Jo-anne McGowan, John Smithson, Arrow Pictures, Dogwoof, River Production Pty Ltd, Stranger Than Fiction Films, Jen Peedom and Robert Macfarlane
end.brief_description: A cinematic and musical odyssey that explores the remarkable relationship between humans and rivers. Throughout history, rivers have shaped our landscapes and our journeys; flowed through our cultures and dreams. RIVER takes its audience on a journey through space and time; spanning six continents, and drawing on extraordinary contemporary cinematography, including satellite filming, the film shows rivers on scales and from perspectives never seen before. Its union of image, music and sparse, the poetic script will create a film that is both dream-like and powerful, honouring the wildness of rivers but also recognizes their vulnerability.

results.name: Weaving a dark web
results.description:
In contemporary Hollywood cinema, children's films often align with comedy and musical genres. However, harking back to the days of European fairytales (and certainly beyond), children's stories are historically dark in tone and were written for both children and adult audiences alike. 
With an apocalyptic threat looming large, Moomins and the Comet Chase veers more into darker territory. However, it is the talented voice cast that conjures some connections to some pure cinema darkness.

key_work.title: Moomins and the Comet Chase
key_work.creator_credit: Maria Lindberg, Ilkka Peltola, Tom Carpelan, Filmkompaniet, Jupiter-Film, Se-Ma-For, Anders Larsson, Iivo Baric, Joel Backström and Minna Karvonen
key_work.brief_description: One day Moomintroll wakes to notice that grey dust is covering everything in the Moominvalley. He runs to ask the philosophical Muskrat if he knows what is happening, who advises him that things tend to look like this before an awful fate coming from the sky hits the Earth. With the help of his father, Moominpappa, Moomintroll and his close friends Sniff and Snufkin build a raft and head out on a challenging journey to the observatory in the Lonely Mountains hoping to find out more from the wise professors there. The friends have to overcome several adversities in order to make it there. When they arrive, they find the professors deep in calculations. They reveal that a comet will reach the Earth in four days, four hours, four minutes and 44 seconds.

video_links.name: AHEAD OF THE CURVE // Official Trailer

end.brief_description: With a fist full of credit cards, a lucky run at the horse track, and a title that called to mind a certain French film star, Franco Stevens launched the best-selling lesbian lifestyle magazine ever published, connecting her community in an unprecedented way. AHEAD OF THE CURVE is a new feature documentary about the extraordinary woman who started Curve magazine, and by doing so helped accelerate the political and social evolution of the nation.

end.title: Go fish
end.creator_credit: Rose Troche, Guinevere Turner, Can I Watch Pictures, Islet and KVPI
end.brief_description: Shot in black and white, on a low budget and using a predominantly non-professional cast, Rose Troche’s first feature offers an inside view of lesbian life in the ‘90’s. Max is looking for love, Ely suffers from a long distance relationship and their scheming friends are determined to match them. Navigated by a wistful narration, the film tracks the inter-linked cast of characters from cafes and bookshops to dinner parties, dates and sex. Starring Guinevere Turner, V. S. Brodie, T. Wendy McMillan, Migdalia Melendez and Anastasia Sharp. Screenplay by Rose Troche and Guinevere Turner.

end.brief_description: A group of lesbian friends struggle with romance and careers in Los Angeles.

constellations_other.name: Charting queer connections
constellations_other.description: The infamous ‘Incest Map’ in Heartbreak High charts connections between Hartley High students, instigating the drama that unfolds in the series. Explore this fictional map’s connections to lesbian media that has been integral to building lesbian community and culture.

links.description: The pilot of The L Word introduces audiences to The Chart: a strikingly similar map to the one featured in Heartbreak High that documents the love, connections and heartbreaks of the lesbian community in LA.

start.title: Legally blonde
start.creator_credit: Robert Luketic, Marc Platt, Ric Kidney and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
start.brief_description: A lively comedy by Australian filmmaker, and Swinburne graduate, Robert Luketic. Reese Witherspoon stars as fashion merchandising graduate, Elle Woods, eagerly anticipating a marriage proposal from her politically ambitious boyfriend, Warner Huntington III (Matthew Davis). When he dumps her to search for a woman more suited to the role of senator’s wife, Elle sets out to win him back. Determined to improve her chances by becoming his intellectual equal, she enrols into Harvard Law School after her vibrant application impresses the admissions board. Her Southern Californian Bimbo appearance, bubbly personality and casual approach to study set her apart from the other Ivy League students. Initially an outcast, Elle’s blonde ambition eventually secures her reputation as a force to be reckoned with, propelling her to the top of her class. Cast also includes: Luke Wilson, Selma Blair and Raquel Welch. Screenplay by Karen McCullah Lutz and Kirsten Smith, based on the book by Amanda Brown. Cinematography, Anthony B. Richmond.

constellations_other.name: The Third Place
constellations_other.description: Explore how Eddie’s Lil’ Homies fits into the broader history of the third place on screen, demonstrating how public spaces away from home, work and school are important sites for friendship, community building and support across generations.

constellations_other.name: Pink subversions
constellations_other.description: Pink dominates Angela Tiatia's The Dark Current. The artist describes this particular colour as “artificial”, “unapologetic” and “pulsating with feminine energy”. In Tiatia's Sāmoan heritage “there is a brashness in the use of colour. I really wanted to embody that.”

end.title: The Lesbian Bar Project
end.creator_credit: Elina Street, Erica Rose, Katie Schiller and The Katz Company
end.brief_description: This 3 part series spotlights the heartfelt, hilarious, and human stories behind the few remaining Lesbian Bars in the country.

links.description: In Legally Blonde, Neptune’s Beauty Nook is a place where women find community and support one another. Filmmakers Erica Rose and Elina Street similarly advocate for and support lesbian bar owners and community spaces through their docuseries Lesbian Bar Project.

start.title: Midnight Diner
start.creator_credit: Shinichi Fushima, AMUSE, atmovie and Geek Sight
start.brief_description: Set in a small restaurant in the corner of a shopping district. The unusual eatery is only open after midnight, and its standard menu consists of just a single choice. However, the customers still come for the amusing chatter and the proprietor’s willingness to cook any dish that they request. This drama depicts the lives of the restaurant’s patrons, including a yakuza, an unsuccessful actor, a group of office ladies, a newspaper delivery boy, and a stripper.

start.headline_credit: United Kingdom and United States of America, 2023
start.brief_description: Barbie and Ken are having the time of their lives in the colorful and seemingly perfect world of Barbie Land. However, when they get a chance to go to the real world, they soon discover the joys and perils of living among humans.

constellations_other.description: Discover how design and aesthetics from 1950s and 1960s have been utilized in female stories on screen, revealing how screen makers draw on the perceived optimism and social realities of the period to highlight women’s experiences.

links.description: Two parents magically become their child’s hand-made dolls and must work together to become human again in the videogame It Takes Two. Similarly dolls Barbie and Ken in Barbie magically become human as they travel to the real world.

start.title: Alice
start.creator_credit: Jan Svankmajer, Peter-Christian Fueter, Condor Features, Film Four International and Hessischer Rundfunk
start.brief_description: In a wonderland populated by an array of superbly animated puppets, steaks crawl, rolls sprout nails and Alice (the only human in the film), not only shrinks, but becomes her own doll. Czech surrealist Jan Svankmajer’s definitive version of “Alice’s adventures in Wonderland” is a distinctive vision which remains true to the absurd and menacing spirit of Lewis Carroll’s work.

start.title: Labyrinth
start.creator_credit: Jim Henson, Eric Rattray and Lucasfilm, Ltd.
start.brief_description: Take a journey into the Labyrinth, where nothing is as it seems. Sarah (Jennifer Connelly) spends most of her time play-acting scenes from her favourite book, The Labyrinth, or baby-sitting her younger brother, Toby. One night, frustrated with Toby’s incessant crying, she begs the goblins to take him away. When Toby actually disappears, Sarah follows him into the world of the wicked Goblin King (David Bowie), where she is given thirteen hours to conquer the Labyrinth, before her baby brother is turned into a goblin forever. An engaging fantasy film, populated by creatures created by Jim Henson’s Creature Shop, and drawing inspiration from a number of sources, including the works of Brian Froud, Maurice Sendak and M. C. Escher. Includes a special behind-the-scenes featurette detailing the making of Labyrinth.

links.description: Jim Henson directed the musical fantasy film Labyrinth, as well as producing it through his production company. Jim Henson Company went onto later produce a similarly darker children’s film Guillermo del Toro’s Pinocchio.
